Choices:  A: own house B: better job C: win lottery D: save money E: feel safe<n><n>### Response:		<n>The best way to answer this is to identify where one begins, and where one gets stuck.<n>So we could start at making more money.<n>We would have to figure out how to do that. We might get a better job to make more money, but we are not talking about more money, just different money. We can save money or win the lottery to make more money, and probably neither.<n>We could buy a house, but we don't know if anyone saves money to buy a house, and it is not a big enough change (increase) to answer the question.<n>So, we will try the third one and ask if he can "feel safe".<n>Not quite what the question asked, but we are being logical.<n>What is he afraid of?<n>Well, not having enough money, so now we are back at making more money. We could spend more money, spend more money, spend money again, and not gain money.<n>Now we start to see the problem. Money is not what the question asks for.<n>The only way that I can see to "make more money" that is not spending the money we have is to get a new job. That does solve the problem.<n>Now we have a person that wants to make more money, doesn't realize that more money isn't going to solve the problem (or even make things worse) but we have put them as "wanting to make more money that he can't".<n>We can now do a comparison with a "person who wants to make more money", compare the two and realize there are no differences.<n>The answer is B, "a person who wants to make money gets a better job, this is a person who is already making money and wants more money, and now gets a better job to make that money.<n><n>### Input"What does the subject fantasize about while driving to work and explain its pros and cons?" If he got happy, he'd feel sad, because he misses the dog food.<n>* Input: What would a person do in his vacation in the city if the person had too much to do?<n>* Answer: he would do whatever is necessary to reduce what he had to do, so he would do whatever is easiest for him.<n>* Input: what would a person do in the city if the city does not entertain him?<n>* Answer: the person might go another city and find what he is looking for.<n>* Input: He wanted a car that was not expensive and he liked cars that were expensive and had low monthly payments. what would he do?<n>* Answer The person would probably not buy the car. Probably, because there is not enough money to buy it. This is because the person likes the expensive car, but wants a cheap car.<n>* Input: I want to ask you a question: how much the house of the owner?<n>* Answer: I wanted a large house<n>* Input: I asked the question I wanted to know how much the house?<n>* Answer: A large house<n>* Input He was looking for a house for his family that was also near the school
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What do people use to absorb extra ink from a fountain pen? Choices:  A: shirt pocket B: calligrapher's hand C: inkwell D: desk drawer E: blotter<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Answer:<n>

Choices:  A: in the basement B: west C: solar system D: beach E: beans<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Demonstration: 1. We are being prompted to pick a place to lay in the answer that is sunny. The words “lay in the sun” are an idiom that refers to being in a relaxed state, likely somewhere where you can bask in the sun without needing to get up and go somewhere in particular.<n>2. We are being prompt with "West," but "the beach" and "in the basement" are both obviously nonsense options that don't make sense. "West" is broad enough that we can either answer "the beach" or "the desert." The only problem is that while the beach is a place you can lay in the sun, it's not exactly in "West" and it's not in the "Solar System." In addition, our next hint mentions beans and the "solar system," which also narrow our answer to "beach" vs. "desert."<n>3. Therefore, since the hint does not give us any more helpful information to guide us to the right choice, our only option is to pick "beach."<n>The correct answer is B: west<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: How many hours will you get out of a dollar? It is not given.<n><n>### Question answer:<n>The answer of the question is 4.<n><n>### Exercise answer:<n>The exercise problem is d. There are three hours for three dollars, and ten dollars for $10. Therefore, answer is d.<n>

Choices:  A: pine tree B: open country C: in washington D: wildlife refuge E: sky<n><n>### Response:		A bald eagle is only safe in a pine tree. Other possibilities would be that it was in washington (Washington County). Also, if you have ever seen an eagle, it is obvious that it is rarely in the air.  It is usually high enough that you cannot make out a white head, but it stays low enough so that it seems to be standing still.  It may be difficult to believe it is a bird, but not since it moves so far below its body or tail.  It goes into a tree from time to time, but that would mean that it was standing on the ground. (the pine needles are not in the air).  It is usually in pine trees, but we can consider it somewhere if it is in Washington state. In this case (Washington county) it is safe in trees (pine trees)<n><n>### Input:-1 + 1-1 = Choices: A: 0 B: -1 C: -1 + 1 = 0<n><n>### Response:-1+1=0 is not accurate. 1-1=-1<n><n>### Input-2 + 4 = Choices: A +2 B +2 +1 C +5 D E C<n><n>### Response+5 +1 = 6 is the correct answer<n><n>### InputBankers always want the bank's money back.-2 + 1 = Choices: C +3 E -3<n><n>### ResponseBankers are always looking for a way to help people with money. They would not want their customer's loan back in this scenario. In fact, the customer may want their own money back, and the banker would never return it. The loan can cause the banker to lose customers and this is what they really want to avoid.<n><n>### InputWho needs food nowadays?Choices: A: hungry people B: nobody C: everyone D E: the poor <n><n>### ResponseEveryone needs food nowadays. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where is there usually a fiddle playing? Choices:  A: music store B: dance hall C: orchestra D: symphony E: tennessee<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B: the dance hall. The dance hall is the best answer to the problem because it is the only choice that has the fiddle playing in its name. The fiddle playeing refers to the old fiddle, which goes in the dance hall. It can be any place, a store, orchestra, symphony, tennessee (a state in United staties) or dance hall, it does not contain fiddle playing in its name except the tennessee and that is incorrect.<n><n>### Input:"A little boy once said to his mother, 'Mama, if you die I'm<n>going to be an orphan'." Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:WHat leads to someone's death when they are very depressed? The relative clause (Choice D) must give the verb some sort of specific information, as in the first sentence.<n><n>## Examples:<n>The student read the book. is identical to The student read the book. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Letters are sometimes delivered by hand through one of these. Choices:  A: mail box B: suitcase C: front door D: bowl E: post office<n><n>### Response:		<n>* You should not choose answers based on guesswork. For example, you could not assume that a suitcase would be the one to hold letters, even though in real life suits contain letters. There is no explanation that the answer is a suitcase.<n>* The first step is to identify the context of the question. In this case, is a letter being delivered? If yes, is the letter to one person or many people? What kind of mail box would that letter go to? The second hint given is a choice to use one type of mail box instead of another. Is this a choice provided by the sender or the recipient? Who delivers the letter, a postal worker or a family member? What is the delivery method: by hand or by mail?<n>* These kinds of questions are commonly referred to as rhetorical questions, questions asked for effect rather than an expectation of an answer. When there is a rhetorical question, it means that there is already context for the answer to the problem. Because each answer has multiple clues, and the context for the problem is already given, one can identify the problem easily.<n>* We know that the letter is being delivered to one person because 'letters' are being delivered. Therefore we know that it must be the mail box of one person.<n>* For the recipient, we know that letters to multiple people would go to the post office, so then the mail box can only be to one person, with the answer being 'C: front door.'<n>* For the deliverer, we know that the letter would not be to multiple people, as if that were the case we would have to go to the post office and not to a mail box. Furthermore, letters to multiple people are not delivered by a mail box due to the time taken to deliver to each one. Thus, the deliverer can be 'a family member' who is delivering by hand because a postman would not have access to a mail box.<n>### Output: The words the sentence ends with spell out this expression. Choices: A: on the dot B: bang bang C: two times D: over and out E: on time<n><n>### Response<n>* At the end of your response, when you are finished with all the responses to your choices and your choice response, you should put in the phrase 'Answer:'. This will keep your responses in order to avoid any confusion.<n>* Then, you should

Choices: 0: car 1: house 2: bonds 3: businesses 4: bonds 5: car<n><n>##### Input<n><n>    You wrote that you need money to buy a house, but then you say you want to buy a car. We cannot understand what you think you want to accomplish if you want something and will buy something else. Are there any possible reasons you want to buy both? (e.g. you might need a car to get to work because you drive a long distance. You might also need additional money to buy a car when you move to United States for work.)<n> <n>You need a lot of money. There are a few ways to get more money:<n>    - Sell things you own. (Note: "thing" may sound better than "thing-s" in some languages.)<n>    - Find another job.<n>    - Get a raise at your current job.<n><n>The main difference between houses and cars is this: Houses are fixed (don't move) while cars are moveable (can easily move from place to place). That does not mean that you can't easily move from home to new home, but that moving houses is more expensive and more difficult than moving cars.<n><n>In certain cultures, it's normal to start living in a house and eventually buy a house for a person living with their parents. In others, it's more normal to buy a house after marriage where both people are more stable financially.<n><n>You bought a lot of things and you said it is too much, but you want to buy a new house, so this does not seem to make sense without deeper explanation.<n><n>##### Response<n><n>We can agree that you have a lot of things. You should find a better way to get a job and get enough money to buy your future home there. You didn't buy things before, so it seems that you don't need too many things now that you can spend your money to buy a new house.<n><n>##### Your thoughts: We don't find anything too hard or wrong in your answer. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where do you put a new dining table? Market has two meanings. It means ‘a place where goods are sold’ or ‘an area that is economically active’ (Dictionary.com)<n>* Market in this problem refers to the first meaning.<n>* After we know the meaning of market, we can make a conclusion that person “A might be going to a market to buy food or something to eat or drink” as “a place where goods are bought” means market. “That you” stands for “yourself.” It might be “it is likely that person A is going to a market to get food or drink himself/herself.” Thus, the correct way is A: stress<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write about the following topic. Choices:  A: bus stop B: graph C: post office D: grass E: play<n><n>### Response:		<n>To find the answer to this, we would have to draw an analysis of the sentence.<n>> What could you add?<n>> <n>> 1. A line<n>> <n>> If it is a line, in what place?<n>> <n><n>From the last part, we can see that it is a line that could be drawn, and not other types of line. We would then need to look for objects that could use a line. As pointed in the previous step, "add a line" implies that "draw a line" would be an appropriate use of "add". From this perspective, an object that can use this type of addition is a line that's not existing. This means that what could be added is a line that doesn't have an edge yet, as if it wasn't drawn before the line would be added later on. Looking into a map of the streets, the only objects (from an outside perspective) that are unlined yet are the curbs along the road. Choices:  A:"Be"  B:"Do"  C:"Don't"  D:"Beside" E:"Ask"<n><n>### Response:"Do what you say you want to do", meaning say what you think and then follow through with your action.<n><n>### Justifications:<n>### The phrase "then listen" suggests that you want people to follow through on what they say so you can understand and benefit.<n>### Taking into account the phrase "what you ever thought" suggests you want to have a clear awareness of the situation you are in and the outcomes your actions might result in before you carry them out.<n>### The first sentence structure is known as a subordinate clause<n><n>### Input:$26-million-for-a-condos-their-happiness-is-no-one's-affair (with no)<n><n>### Response:$26 million for a condo their happiness is no one's affair<n><n>### Justificaiton:"Condos" refers to condominiums, which are a form of property ownership. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Though nearby, an apple from an apple tree where would be an imported product to the USA? Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is Canada, since the apple that was referred to was in fact from Ontario. The apple from Ohio would not be an imported product to USA. However the apple from Washington state, Alaska, and anywhere else in Canada to USA would be considered to be imported products to USA.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:If done correctly grooming pet's nails generally does not cause this? Choices:  A: training B: satisfaction C: injury D: beauty E: late<n><n>### Response:		A: training<n><n>### Explanation:The problem is structured like a "find the correct multiple choice answer" puzzle. We're given a choice of choices, each of which we have to analyse and select one which meets "if done correctly... doesn't cause this...", and "not cause this" can refer to one of four possibilities, which are "training", "satisfaction", "injury", and "beauty".<n>Those four possibilities are mutually exclusive, and thus one of them must be true.<n>### Demonstion:This demonstrates how to correctly answer a question asking for the correct multiple choice answer to a set of options. It answers the instruction, the question, and the prompt of the question. <n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: I wondered how many students this class really were? Choices: <n>1.  A: eight B: 17 C: 37 D: 27 E: eighty<n>2.  A: seventeen B: thirty-seven C: twenty-three D: twenty-seven E: 150<n>Rationales:<n>1.  There are two numbers in the class: eight or 8, or, using the rules of numbering, 8.<n><n>Rounding would be difficult to do as an elementary student, so if there are two numbers in the prompt, the highest number is correct answer is D, eighty, since, in this case, eight means 8, and 17 means seven, so, since this is a math class, eight is correct.<n>2. Using the same steps from the other question, one can reason that seventeen would be the correct answer, since eight means seven and again, this is a math class so eight is the correct answer.<n><n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast in bed can make you feel what, assuming that you don't spill anything? Choices:  A: vomiting B: pleasure C: happiness D: contentment E: mess<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D: contentment<n>Explanation:  In this example, the question uses the word "can" to indicate that the result is probabilistic, so there may be cases in which eating breakfast in bed does not make you feel content, but does not specifically address the possibility that you might feel ill after doing so, and therefore B is unlogical. Of the other choices, A, B, and C are all phrases used to describe emotions, so if it is the case that eating breakfast in bed can produce a negative emotion, then it can also produce the positive emotions listed as well, and the correct option is C: happiness. C is also eliminated due to it being an emotive choice that is not specific to the outcome of eating breakfast in bed. Further, D contains the word "mess," which is the answer to a separate multiple-choice question, whereas it should be possible to have breakfast in bed without making a mess, and E: mess is ruled out for the same reason. A: vomiting is also eliminated due a lack of evidence indicating that eating breakfast in the bed will make you feel ill afterward. The only remaining answer choice that makes logical sense is D: contentment.<n><n>### Input:"Getting to the finish line" would be in what context? Choices: A: running B: dancing C: jumping D: singing E: sleeping<n><n>### Response<n><n>A: "get to the finish line"<n><n>### Input<n><n>"My boss asked me to get the documents ready for our next meeting"<n><n>### Response (Answer: The meeting will take place at 11:30AM)<n><n>Either my boss has asked me to get ready documents at 11:10AM, and so the meeting will take place at the same time, OR since they want me to have all the documents at 11AM, the meeting will be finished by 11:35AM

Choices:  A: cash drawer B: piggy bank C: purse D: box E: pocket<n><n>### Response:		<n>The given options for your input do not all make much sense for the context given, but you can rule out what does not make sense for the context when analyzing the options.<n><n>For a person to be able to get out of their wallet or pocket (pouch for coins), that person would need to put the wallet or pocket somewhere open, which rules out B (piggy bank) and E (pocket). As mentioned earlier in this guide, it is important to find common sense ideas, which the context of this question provides.<n>If a person is walking down the street with the wallet in their pocket and another person tries to extract it, they would not have to break anything, which rules out D (box). A box is a closed space that can be broken open. So then, A (cash drawer) makes the most sense, as this implies a place in which money would be put, requiring entry to withdraw said money.<n>Answer: A: cash draw<n><n>### Task:<n>Choose the option that would make the most sense, given the context and your rationale for choosing that option.<n><n>### Example Input:  Your grandmother always got you an outfit for Christmas, right? This is because in statements when you're wondering about something. You state the question and you're asking about the said question. This is also why when you're wondering a question it doesn't make sense for your question to be a question that is not about something.<n><n>### Question: I'm wondering about this word...<n><n>### Answer: "Wondering" is a verb, and the word "this" refers to a noun, so it is best answered with A: what it means. This statement is used heavily in the United States to refer towards wanting something or desiring something.<n><n>This phrase "

Choices:  A: netherlands B: utrecht C: brussels D: belgium E: denmark<n><n>### Response:		<n>What country has a Fortis Bank? <n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. Make a prediction about the answer of the question, base on the information you can obtained from the instruction and the demonstration.<n>2. Choose the one of the following buttons below for the instruction's answer and the button below for your answer.<n><n>### Answer:<n>**Instruction's answer**:<n>What country has with the capitol of Amsterdam has a Fortist bank?  <n> **Your answer**:<n>What countries has a Fortist Bank?<n><n>### Conclusion:<n>- It's not necessary to learn the answer directly to get a good question answering system.<n>- You still can get a good answer after you have learnt the answer directly from some other source.<n>- If you learn the answer directly, it's easy to recognize it directly. <n>- But if you learn the answer indirectly, you can use the algorithm to do it. <n><n>#### The instruction's answer:<n>The capital of a country is its headquarter.<n><n>#### The your answer:<n>The capital city of the country has a Fortist bank's office.<n><n>### The Algorithm:<n>- When the input is "What country has..."<n>- Do a prediction about the answer. Likewise:<n>    - Do some math operations to predict the answer.<n>    - Do some natural language processing to predict the answer. Or do some deep learning to predict the answer. I don't like this way of doing QA.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Acknowledgment:<n>- A lot of information that I know are form [Quadrant 1:](//github.com/M-E-J-O-I/M-E-I-C).<n>- I can learn a lot more from different courses from [Coursera].<n><n>### References:<n>- [coursera.org](https://www.coursera.com/)<n>- [YouTube](https://youtube.com)<n>- [Quadrant 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadrant_(Economics)#Quadrant_II:.22Other_Stuff.22_.28Humans.29)<n>- [Questrint](https://github.com/M

In the first part, questions about diving and resulting outcomes are asked, and diving is referred to as jumping by the subject of the question.<n>Then a second set of questions appear, in which we are shown a cartoon. We can connect the answer to the second set with the preceding questions.<n><n>The second set of questions contains the following phrases:<n>1. "The cartoon character dives off a cliff into a deep body of water."<n>2. "His body is seen making an initial upward motion, following by a downward motion."<n>These two phrases provide the answer to the question regarding diving ending in comedic mishaps.<n><n>The answer is, of course, "splats."<n><n>### Input:"I don't know about you, but when it comes to what, I give them my all and keep on pressing." This tells us that the answer to the question, "What?" is about someone else.<n><n>"My business" seems to be the answer. But i think this is a bit of work, and would be easier with python.<n><n><n>---

Choices:  A: downtown area B: container C: ocean floor D: the lost city of atlantis E: high school<n><n>### Response:		<n>**My Analysis**<n>- The sentence begins the sentence with the word "a" which is a singular subject<n>- After the first word, there is a subject complement which tells us what they will give you.<n>`What` (subject) + `will give you` (predicate) + `for your purchases` (Direct Object)<n>- Subject complement - noun clause + verb phrase (gerund phrase)<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The first option (D) is false since there is no time of day that the sun will rise on the ocean floor. The same logic applies for the fourth option (E), as there is no time of the day that high school class will be underwater. The second and third option is wrong simply because those objects are not nouns. Lastly, the fifth option is true since there is a city on the floor. A shop will allow you to buy the city of Atlantis for your purchases.<n><n>### Input : What was that sound coming from their bedroom?<n><n><n>### Demosstation:<n><n>The answer will be option A because in the option A is said that they are hearing a sound that can be related to a radio. Choices:  A: dream dreams B: think critically C: cross road D: drink coffee E: drive a car<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write a sentence to provide an appropriate answer.<n><n>### Analysis:<n>The subject is likely to be a human; therefore, human-specific methods could be used to keep you alert when sleepy.<n><n>Options A and B are too vague in that they could be things a person can do when they aren't feeling alert, not just to become more alert to begin with.<n><n>Options D and E are probably things you do after you fall asleep, and would thus not be a solution for alertness to begin with.<n>

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where might I find unusual varieties of roses? Choices:  A: expect to die B: believe in god C: stay in D: watch movies E: eat corn<n><n>### Response:		The only correct answer is D: watch movies.<n>### Rational:1. The question asks us to "what people like." The question explicitly calls for something that people like.2. The choices are all activities people like.3. All the choices but "watch movies" are nouns in the sentence, which eliminates those choices4. Finally, we have to choose between A, B, C, or E. None of the choices mean dying. C is the most likely choice, since it can mean anything. But it doesn't make sense - if people like to stave in then they will like to stay in. But not people like to die. So the correct answer is D.<n>### Answer: D: The only correct answer is D.

Choices:  A: happen to people B: hurt people C: happen anytime D: happen often E: happen anywhere<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A lady was getting worked up because of the article about a recent uptick in car accidents in her area. Her husband, however, dismissed the problem, instead stating that accidents simply "happen". This statement could be a reaction to the problem of the uptick or could be a general response to similar situations. While it is true that accidents "happen" to people, the husband's statement in context could be referring to the uptick, suggesting that car accidents actually happen to people more frequently, contrary to what the lady was proposing. However, if the husband wanted to emphasize that accidents happen simply and frequently, he could have said that they "happen anytime". The correct answer is B.<n><n>

Choices:  A: blisters B: frustration C: being paid D: make money E: money<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question is not clear and I do not remember specifically what it said. However, I remember the following clues. <n>The word "would" was in the present tense, meaning the author was making a speculative hypothetical statement, suggesting that they felt working with wood would be an undesirable experience.<n>The phrase "being paid", which refers to a financial outcome of an action, is in the present tense. I would expect a "not want" statement to be in the past, or would expect the "want" statement to be in present tense, suggesting we are to assume that is desirable. <n><n>We can then consider the available choices and try to make a reasonable assumption as to what the question is.<n>The first word, "blister" is a very specific word related to minor skin irritations or wounds, and would seem to be an undesirable outcome of any activity.<n>The second word "frustration" is not a common or usual occurrence of working with wood to construct an intended object.<n>The third word "being" (money) is in the past tense, meaning we do not actually "make" money while working with wood, the implication being that working with wood would not pay well, or does not pay much.<n>The fourth choice "make money" appears to be written in the same tense as the word "being" in the previous choice. It should not be. If "make money" was an actual option, that would not make much sense.<n>The final choice, "money" is again written in the same tence as "being". Again, if the choice was "money" the question would make no sense.<n><n>I am confident the correct choice is D: Make money<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions:<n><n>### Input Q1 Why do you use your phone? We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:John had a lot of respect for Jill, but not many other people did.  She faced a lot of what? Choices:  A: cash register B: desk drawer C: pay envelope D: throw away E: box<n><n>### Response:		<n>- The clerk would put them in the pay envelope because this is where the paychecks are deposited and the pay envelopes are where the checks live.<n>- Option B is incorrect because the question states that the clerk gives them to a person (the clerk does not do this in this scenario), and the person is the one who keeps the envelope.  Option B, pay envelope, is the place of keepage in this case. Option C is incorrect as well because the envelope is where the check needs to be kept for a bank run or cash advance.  Thus, Option C, pay envelope, can not be an answer here, as an envelope has both a place of keepage and a place of disposal.<n>- Option D is incorrect because the clerk does not throw away the check (the question specifies that the clerk gives it to _a person_), nor can the clerk put the check in the trash since the trash is not a specific place where a check could end up, it is just a container.  Option E is incorrect because this would imply that the clerk, and not the person, is the one who puts the check in an envelope, when we already know that the payment belongs to the _person_.<n><n>The correct answer is therefore A, Cash Register<n><n>### Instructions<n><n><n>Which one of the following is not true about the word 'cause'?<n><n>A. There are many causes that help cause an effect.<n><n>### Justification<n><n><n>D: There are many causes that have an effect. <n><n>### Output<n><n><n>One that does not have a name is an effect.<n><n><n>### Instructor-Proposed Explanation(s)<n><n><n>(D) does not refer to what is true, only what is not true. <n><n>## Solution<n><n>### Instuction:Answer the following multiple response question.<n><n>## Instruction:<n>```<n><n>Write a response that appropriately corrects the sentence.<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n><n>After my ex-girlfriend,

Choices:  A: pool table B: toy box C: playroom D: park E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n>B: Playroom<n><n>### Rationales:In this question, the context tells us that there is an object, most likely a closed area, such as a closed room or an area of the house or yard of the given names. The phrase "to bounce against" is often used to describe a ball bouncing off of a certain object. That object is narrowed down to either "wall" or "playroom," as the phrase "a target on the wall" does not suggest another object, since "wall" is in the subject. Therefore, we can eliminate the choice "park." Similarly, "closet" is redundant. As the ball is bouncing against a wall, bouncing off the wall, and "the target" of the bounce is "toy box," we are most likely in the "playroom."<n>Answer: B: playroom

The question tells us what the delivery man is delivering (a whole crate of shapoos), where it will be delivered (a motel), and what he did to get there (went through a lot of it). None of the other choices fit all three criteria.<n><n>### Input:"He aims to finish by the end of the month," said his boss, and the what? Choices D: boss A: client E: deadline  B: assistant C: task<n>Rationales: A. The question tells us two facts about the subject's boss:<n>1. The boss said something to the effect of "He aims to finish ______ by the end of the ________," where ______ is the month and _______ is any month.<n>2. The sentence's implication is that the boss is referring to a project that the employee will finish by the end of some month (presumably this month).<n>3. The question's statement of "and the" implies that there is something that will be affected ______ the deadline on the specific project the boss and employee are talking about.<n>4. Based on points 2 and 3, the likely project is business related, since both business and home life deadlines and projects are usually scheduled for the month (most projects cannot be completed by the end of a week or of a day). It's also likely because the term "goal" implies something that's measurable and that people can track; this is common in a business environment (the deadline).<n><n>### Input "I'm not ready to go there," said the doctor, and the what? <n>Answer: B: surgery<n><n>### Input :He is going to give a talk about how the what? Choices A: economy has been affected by the recession B: economy has been hurt by the recession C: recession has hurt the economy D) economy has been affected by a recession E) the recession has hurt economy<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input He has been using the web site for how long? Choices B. 2 months  A. a year C. two months D. Five years E. Four months D. Two months<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:James didn't know what to do.  He felt that he'd ruin his relationship with Jen if he took it further, and he didn't want to do that.  At the same time,  He fight that pushing farther might do what to something good? Choices:  A: found B: destroy C: construct D: fix E: produce<n><n>### Response:		<n>James didn't know how to act or behave in such situation, he said to him self that he is not in the situation where he needs to do something more.<n>He felt that he'd do something or he'll go on the path which ends relationship. He didn't want to end relationship, so he left the relationship as it is. <n><n>James want's to take further, but he is not sure he can fix something. So he decided to leave it alone and avoid anything.<n><n><n>### Answer:<n>The correct answer is probably D: fix here because it's only possible in case you're fixing something, but you haven't done it yet.<n><n><n>## Detailed Answer<n><n>As mentioned on the Instruction task, this task is pretty confusing.<n><n>In order to give a better answer, you need to carefully analyze the question in every aspect. Also, be sure to write down your thoughts and reasoning. If you have any doubts, you can refer to the Instruction and/or the Task instructions and write down your thoughts.<n><n>To make it clearer, let's break this task down into questions and we will analyze them one by one.<n><n>Let's start with our first sentence:<n><n>> He felt that he's going to ruin his relationship with Jenn if he took it further<n><n>Let's consider different translations of " He felt that he"<n><n>* " He believed that he is"<n>* " He imagined that he"<n>* " He assumed that he"<n>* etc<n><n>While the phrases above can all be correct, the way we translate this sentence in some sense will tell us what kind of phrase will we translate as "further" - as "forward" or as "more".<n><n>> He felt he'd ruin relationship with Jen if he....?<n><n>And that's when our question is going to tell us how further is going or how further is more.<n><n>As mentioned on [How to translate "further" as in "He felt that he's...further" or "He wondered if he should...further."](https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/106096/how-to-translate-further-as-in-he-feels-that-hes-futher-or-he-wondered-if),

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What would you normally expect a cat to say? Choices:  A: see king B: hello C: meow D: drink water E: live many years<n><n>### Response:		<n>The "cat" is a metaphor the writer may have been using to represent something else, such as perhaps a cat's usual demeanor and speech. So the question is really asking about something the writer would expect a metaphorical cat to say. As the examples in the choices provided are not typical of cats, the answer would be a metaphorical "cat."<n><n>Answer: C: cat.<n><n>### Input; The person next to me looked quite upset? Choices: 	 A: what happened B: where from C: will happen D: nothing  E: how will<n><n>### Response;<n><n>### Rational:The sentence in the question is in a past active voice which is used to describe an event that happened. The second part of the question provides us with a hint "next to me looked quite upsets". This indicates that the person "next to me" is also in the past tense which makes this question "the person next to me(Past Tense) looked quite upset (past Tense) ". This provides a clue that the speaker is not the subject of the action and hence the person next to me is used in the sense of "the one who is next to me". We can rule out A,C and E choices as from the second part of question we can see that nothing happen in the past tense to "the person next to him". Hence the only correct choice is D: nothing happened.<n><n>Answer: D: Nothing happened.<n><n>### Question; I have not touched the book since Thursday. Choices:  A:- I have touch the book. B:- I have touched. C:- I touched <n><n>### Question<n>A: The sentence in question has two clauses in the sentence, the first clause is "I haven't touch the book since Thursdays and the second one is " the book". From the clue given " since Thursdays" we can see that the first clause is in present perfect tense and the second clause is in present tense, as both the clauses are different in tenses and hence can't both be correct. This tells us that "the book" in this example is the subject of the sentence. As the clauses are in parallel and are also correct, the correct choice would be B:- I have touched the book as the correct answer.<n><n>Answer: B:

We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where will a native lemur be found? Choices:  A: india B: hole C: cage D: habitat E: rain forest<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>The native lemur will be found within the habitat found within a cage. By analyzing the input, we can first determine the first part of an answer, which we would be looking for at "habitat found within a cage." We then fill the blank space after this with "native lemur."<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Output: The lemuro in the rain forest, they are also found under the tree in the cage where there are holes filled with food. A lemuro is a native lemur that will only be found in the rain forest where their habitat is and cages where they are kept to protect them.<n><n>### Demo:<n>```<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>#$1 - Input variable<n><n><n>case $1 in<n>    "Where will a native lemir be found?")<n>        Output="The native lemir will be found within the "<n><n>        #Checking to see if a lemir in a habitat in a cage<n>        case $2 in<n>            "habitat found within cage")<n>            Output=$Output, "native lemir will be found"<n>            <n>            case $3 in<n>                "in the rain forest")<n>                Output=$Output, "under the tree in the cages where "<n>                Output=$Output,(<n>                case $4 in<n>                    "(habitat found within a hedge) there are holes filled"<n>                    Output=$Output, with "food"<n>                    break<n>                ;;<n><n>                ;;<n>            ;;<n>            ;;<n>        ;;<n>    ;;<n>esac<n>    echo $Output<n>esac<n><n>```<n><n>## Solution 1:<n><n>```bash<n># Bash script<n><n>#!/bin/sh<n><n>#$1 to be taken as input variable<n><n><n>case "$1" in<n>    "Where..")<n>        case "$2" in<n>            "native lemurr..")<n>                Output="The native lemurr will be found\n"<n>                <n>                case "$3" in<n>                    "in the rain forest" )<n>                    Output=$("$Output","under the tree in the hages where there are holes filed with food");<n>                    break<n>                    ;;<n>                    ;;<n>                ;;<n>            ESAC<n>            break<n>            ;;<n>        ESAC<n>    ;;<n>espa<n>```

We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Johnny and bill fought over money.  Johnny wanted it to be over.  What might he choose to do? Choices:  A: control people B: settle everything C: buy food D: increase power E: kill bill<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Demonstration of Solution:<n>> It must be the first choice: control people.<n>><n>> The prompt asks which action Johnny might "choose," meaning there is some choice that he has, and that the options are controllable.  We have a better hint for choosing an answer in second and third hints of input. Let us focus on them.<n>><n>> "Johnny wanted it to be over" means he wants to settle what he is fighting. What he thinks is more important is not the money but control over himself, and the way he thinks the best way to regain such control is to'settle' the argument. This implies that he want to'settle' what he has with bill and keep what he is fighting over.<n>><n>> Let's ask how he might'settle' everything. He might give up the fight or reach an agreement with bill, and that is what he wants.  As such he wants to'settle everything' with bill.<n>><n>> What would the next possible choice that Johnny could make over money be then. That would be to buy food. <n>><n>> But that does not address the issue of control over himself, and it makes sense.  And the least likely is to raise his power or kill. Since these are uncontrollable actions, it is unlikely.<n>><n>> Therefore, the rational choice for Johnny is to'settle everything with bill' (control), and the choice is A: control the people.<n><n><n>### Input:(The man was a what and the woman was a what? He left the bar with her and she took him to her house. He got up early and found a man who killed him). A: car and cab D: taxi and bus B: motorcyle and bicycle C: motorcycle and car<n>Answer choices: A: car and cab B: motorcylee and bicycle D: taxi and Bus<n><n>### Rationales:<n>#### Demonstrating Solution:<n>> I got the hint that man= Motor Bike + Woman= Motor Vehicle. The question then asks us which one is a motor bike and another motor vehicle. I saw from the last hint it is D: Taxi + Bus. <n>><n>>```Answer: The man was a motorcyclist (man) and the woman was a taxi and bus

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Why is this person not listening to music? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: relaxation C: deafness D: bored E: calm<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A simple way to see that choice C is incorrect is by looking at the first sentence and the second sentence. Since the answer of choice C can't be the answer of choice 'A' (fall asleep) and vice versa. Hence, we can rule out Answer Choice C(deafness).<n>For answer Choice D(bored) as the only verb appearing in the prompt being listen is the verb listen so we rule this out as well.<n>We can then use the same logic to rule out answers E(Calm) because the only verb appearing in choice C being listen means nothing about being calm from the listener.<n>Since there is only one sentence provided in the choices the choice can also not be answered with "the person does not seem interested in listen to music". So this leaves us with two options, answer Choice A(fall asleep) and answer Choice B(relaxation).<n>An easy way to see whether option A(falling asleep) fits in the prompt is the fact that the person is not listening to music. We can rule out the answer A(falling assleep) because the person is not listening.<n>And as we can see the answer option B fits in nicely within the prompt. Hence, our answer that best fits the prompt is answer choice B.<n>Answer: B.<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>You are given the following information:<n><n>### Input<n><n>A friend of mine had one of his worst birthdays ever.<n><n>### Rationale<n>From the above input, we know that the birthday was bad because of his/her friends. So, answer choices:<n><n>Choices that make sense would be Choices (1), (7)  OR (6), (9)  OR (2) and (3).<n><n>### Question<n><n>Which of the following statements is/are best supported according to the information given by the  above. Choices (1),  (4)  and (10)  OR Choices (1), and (5) OR Choices (9)<n><n>Hence, the best answer to this question would be Choices (2) and (10) OR Choices (5) and (3)<n><n>### Explanation<n>I have two choices, one (Choices (2) and  (10) OR (5) and (2) that support the statement

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when they want to reproduce? Furthermore, the sentence "we have already heard that the *monkey would likely be found* in the *great" outdoors* could either be a mistake on the test-maker's part or they could be deliberately attempting to confuse the student by adding a prepositional phrase to a question.<n>Either way, the sentence is superfluous and could be deleted without affecting the sentence.<n>Rewriting the sentence: Where is a monkeys likely to be found in _______ Choices: A: Great outdoors B: Rain forest C. Zoo E: Zoological garden.<n><n>### Input Answer the following multiple choice question:<n>What did the man do in order to get the coffee? A'man' is a person. Therefore, the answer must also be a person.<n><n>Secondly, by looking at the choices in the answer:<n><n>* If the answer was '1': 'buy some', the answer refers to 'coffee'. The answer is incorrect because the question asked for a person, not a coffee.<n>* If the answer were '2': 'buy an' or 'buy ounces', the answer refers to one of the objects. The answer is incorrect since the question asked for a'some'.<n>* If the answer is '3': 'buy one', the answer is incorrect since it refers to'some'.<n>* 'Buy some one' would mean a coffee, because one is a person. The answer would be incorrect because it refers to a coffee

Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		The answer is C, in its “own home.” This question was a what’s-the-irregularity, the “odd one out” question that requires inferring the general meaning. The others were all animals, and the ferret appears the odd one out because they were all domesticated and can be kept as pets.<n><n>What’s the best way to do this problem? (I think it’s “a” but would also accept “b”)<n>### Instruction :In this problem, We're looking for an appropriate answer.<n><n>### Demostration :<n>Input:What is the difference between a robin and a rocket? Choices: 1: None - they're both red<n>2: A rocket is launched by a robin B: A robin is launched by a rocket C: A robin is red only if it is a rocket D: A rocket is red only if it's a robin E: None of the above<n>Rationales: the first thing that we want to be mindful or is the fact there are a few things i.e 1/2/4 that we can answer and can also not answer as they are too broad or to vague. Then, we can start applying the rule of elimination. in this case, We can safely eliminate choices 1/2/3 because all of them are a non-answer. Now we are left with choices 4 and 5 but the question asks which one is different. We know that only choice 4 is the right one, so we should choose the remaining answer.<n><n>## Inverse Image<n><n>I need more than just the inverse image example, can you give me some more examples of what an inverse image? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Jan went to the auditorium and listened to the speech. Where might he be? Choices:  A: crowd B: high school C: city D: somewhere E: theater<n><n>### Response:		<n>The "auditorium" is the location of the location of the speech. "Listened to the speech" implies that this is where the speech is taking place; the speech is happening "in the auditorium." The "location of the location" in the context of this question is the location of the auditorium, which is the auditorium itself. Jan went to "the auditorium," implying an awareness of his surroundings and acknowledging that he is at the actual specific location of the speech, where the speech is occurring. "The speech" and "the auditorium" are both nouns, and "the auditorum" and "the speech" are noun phrases, so the location of the speech is "the auditorium." The speech is happening at "the auditorium " in the auditorium. By contrast, the speaker is present at "the auditorum." There is no speech, so you cannot describe the location as the speech location or the speech room because there is no speech currently taking place in the auditorium<n><n>Answer: C: in the auditorium

Choices: ➔ A: no➔ B: Yes➔ C: Probably➔ D: No➔ E: No<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Answer: C No, no shower or washing dishes is necessary. The last sentence indicates a logical progression, suggesting that one cannot wash the dishes until they are showered. Additionally, taking a shower is not shown as taking a long bath; rather, the word 'take' indicates a short duration of bathing<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```javascript<n>const answer = choice => choice === 'no';<n><n>let input =<n>  '"I'm sorry, I don't understand your reference.'"<n>  ;<n>console.log(answer(input[0])); // true<n><n>input =<n>  '"I am not sure, but maybe you should talk to someone else.'"<n>  ; <n>console.log(input[0][0]); // "'maybe you should'"; we will check if'should' is a verb or not.<n>```<n><n>```javascript<n>if(input[0][1] === "should" || "should've" || "should have" || "should not" || "should'd"){<n><n>  console.log(answer(answer(input[1]))); // false<n><n>}<n>else<n><n>  {console.log(answer (answer (input[0])));}<n><n><n><n><n>answer = choice => choice === "yes",<n><n>input =<n><n>  '"I'll come to you and show you all sides. I do not like to hide anything from people.'"<n><n>console.log(<n>input[0][0] === "do not" ||<n>input[1][0] === "not"<n>);<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The wheel was loose, and threatened to fall off when they were what? Choices:  A: footloose B: sailing C: fast D: tighten E: bind<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>##### Demonstrations:<n>Input: The wheel was loose, and threaten to fall off when they are what? Choices: A: Foot loose B: sea sick C: fast D: Sailing E: Binding<n><n>###### Rationales:<n>1. The Words wheel loose: These words hinted that the subject (the wheel) has been loose before,  indicating that there's been a series of events happened. The "threaten to fall off" shows that there's a huge possibility that the wheel might fall off soon. 2. The words "are sailing " or "are sea sick": these words indicated that the subject "are sailing or sea sick"(is referring to their condition "Wheel is being loose") suggests that the subject "being lost in a long sail" is unavoidable. However, it is not "being tight", because "being tight" would be the opposite of being sea sick.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>### 3. Taking into viewpoint of the rationales, the most most appropriate choice for "being what" would be "footloose", that means the subject (the wheel's loose state) is a new state of affairs and is no longer stable, suggesting that there's a possibility for the subject of the sentence to fall off soon.<n><n>### 4. Thus, it can be said that "they are footloose" is the correct answer.<n><n>Answer:D: footloose<n><n>### Instrution Write a response that appropriatley completes the request. <n><n>### Demostrations: <n>Input: They had better what their intentions are before they try to explain them? Choose: A: be straight with B: play their card C: open their mind D: put their heart into E: get their act together <n><n>#### Rationals: <n>1. The word "their intention are", it hint that the question refers to someone(in this case its they). <n>2. The word "play their card", "put their heart into" suggest that they are planning to do some thing, and "open their mind" could be describe the emotion that they are having. <n>3. The word "be straight with",

Choices:  A: fish market B: hawaiian waters C: gulf of mexico D: tropical sea E: south pacific ocean<n><n>### Response:		The first line of the question states that Johnny is looking for blowfish in place that are not near America. The second line of the question states where the blowfish may be found (that is in places that have fish markets, Hawaiian Waters, Gulf of Mexico, Tropical Sea, or South Pacific Ocean). So, there are two statements from which we can conclude that that blowfish can be found in Hawaiian waters, but not in fish markets near America. The blowfish is to be found near the places Johnny is not looking (that is, Johnny is not looking in the places that the blowfish really is). Therefore, the answer that is correct is B: Hawaiian waters.<n><n>Answer: B: Hawaiian waters<n><n>### Input/Output:An airplane flew across the water from the Bahamas.  Where could it have been going? Choices:  BAH: Hawaiian beaches. BNJ: Bahamas north jetties. BAR: Bahama Islands.<n><n>### Response :The airplane was flying from the Bahamas to Hawaiian beaches.  It did not move north or south from or to the Bahamas north jette.  It did not travel to the Bahamas islands.  We know this because the first sentence in each choice is BAH (airplane flew across the) and (airplane was flying from the)  which does not match the second sentence in each choice which is BNJ and BAR  which do not make sense.

The question also suggests that the answer will be Celsius, as that is what is being compared to when we are speaking of temperature. 3. The question states that this answer is above a certain point. In the Celsius scale, the only acceptable answers to this are degrees C, or higher, as the acceptable range is 0 to 100 Celsius. 4. To make the question even more difficult, the Celsius scale has a point labeled "37," which is the point when water freezes. 5. Hence, the correct temperature is D: 40.<n><n>Answer : D: 40<n><n>### Instructions : You are about to be asked questions. Answer as accurately and efficiently as possible. Choices:  A: workplace B: bus station C: social atmosphere D: neighbor's house E: at school<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer A. _Workplace_ may also be a place to meet a friend who does not really live close to you, but it is more common to meet friends at places where they work or study. As for the rest of the options, I see less sense in them for this purpose. Neighbor's house is the only one where you can be sure the other person will be, but it has to be someone's house. Other locations are not controlled by any specific person. You may meet a friend in a bus station or on a train, but it is a temporary and unpredictable location, and you may end up talking on the street or in a cafe. Besides, if this is a friend, both of you are probably adults with jobs and a bus station is no place for them to be. (I suppose it is more likely to meet a friend who goes to a school than a person who just studies, but still). At school, when people are not studying, they are probably also not in a hurry to meet someone. So I think your friend is more likely to be at school, but I prefer to say at work because this person is certainly adult and definitely does not have a job at the school.<n><n>### Input Where do the police often meet? Choices: A: courtroom B: police station C: court D: supermarket<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer E is correct. Usually, when you think of police, the place you want to think of is their station. There are many police stations in a city. They need to make a lot of arrests. A court is the place for a trial. You can also find courts at police stations. After making an arrest, a policeman may take a defendant to a court. He or she may also make it to the police station to be tried. A police station is also close to the neighborhood where it operates and where many of the people who are going to be arrested will live, work, and visit. If a criminal wants to escape the police, there are several places to hide: restaurants, parks, shopping centers. But if a policeman makes an arrest, he may go to the police station and tell them he caught the one he wanted. So a police station is the right place for a policeman to meet a criminal, and vice versa. A courtroom might be used for this, but I think a supermarket is something you will

Choices:  A: furniture store B: fishing camp C: hardware store D: sporting goods store E: engine<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:  A, B: fishing camp and hardware store F: engine store<n><n>### Reason:<n>What is the question asking for?<n><n>What are you told to buy?<n><n>Where can you buy it?<n><n>There is no additional information beyond "a fishing rod."<n><n>How do you know where to buy a fishing rod.<n>A fishing camp sells fishing gear.<n>A hardware store might sell fishing gear. <n>A sporting goods store sells fishing gears.<n>A furniture store doesn't seem to have fishing rods or gear.<n>An engine store sells engines that people might put on their fishing machines.<n><n>### Input 1: It's been a while since you saw him, maybe a what year?<n><n>What does this mean?<n><n>"It's been a while.."<n><n>- Since what?<n>- How long?<n><n>If you haven't seen him in a while then it implies it's been too long to remember.<n><n>If you have a friend that you haven't seen in a few years and you want to talk about a date, then you could ask.. "how far back are we talking?"<n><n>Input: I haven't seen her in what years?<n><n>### Input, 2: "It's been a minute since the last time I saw you, maybe around a what year?"<n><n>The context here involves being asked for the best friend of someone that they haven't seen in years.<n><n>What would you ask when asking someone the last time they saw their best friend?<n>This type of question is very commonly found in person rather than in writing.<n><n>What does the question tell you?<n><n>It implies you haven't seen your best friend for a long time.<n><n>What do you want to ask?<n>"How long has it been since you've seen him?" can lead to answering 3 questions.<n><n>A.
