Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Someone lacking immortality will one day be? Choices:  A: kick the bucket B: mortal C: dead D: can die E: dying<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I interpreted this as either a future fantasy or wish that the subject has, or as a statement of an ultimate destination. Either interpretation can be correct, and there could be multiple other possibilities. Thus, my response would be A: kick the bucket. <n><n>### Input :An adverse effect of the pandemic is? Choices: 1. More business casual dressing 2. The use of masks 3. More business 4. Faster Internet 5. Zoom meetings<n><n># Instruction<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Most of these are false choices. Zoom meetings aren't an inherently positive effect of the pandemic. Internet speed was already increasing pre-pandemic. Dressing more casual wasn't a result of the pandemic (either way you could still be wearing formal pants for it) The pandemic has also not promoted business<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>```<n>    function printSolution(data, choices) {<n>        var output = `<p>My Choice: <input name="${data.question}">`<n>    }<n>```<n>``` <n>    function printScore(){<n>	output += `<p>Score: <input name="score.question" id="score">, <n>    <a id="replay" href="#">replay</a>`<n>	}<n><n>        output += `<n>	<n>	<n>	<n><n>	`<n>        output += getFeedback();<n>        output += `Your Score: ${score.score} points`<n><n>        $(document.getElementById("replay")).click(replay);<n>        <n>        return output;<n><n>    }<n>```

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What enables most people to transport themselves? Choices:  A: helicopter B: own cars C: speak words D: believe in god E: dance together<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rational:<n>The correct answer can be found in the first stanza of the question. <n>```<n>Most people<n>```<n>This means people in general. If the question asked us for our opinions about the means of transportation, we would need to change the whole sentence, making it an inquiry instead of an assumption.<n>```<n>have to transport themselves.<n>```<n>This means moving from one place to another requires transport; as stated, it is a requirement.<n>```<n>If you want to move from L.A. to San Diego,<n>```<n>If we want to move from Los Angeles to San Diego, it is obvious that we will use cars to do so. However, if L.A. and San Diego were connected via a train line, the whole statement would not be an assumption anymore.<n>```<n>you would have to<n>```<n>We would have to if we wanted to move from L. A. and use a train to San Diego.<n>```<n>use cars <n>```<n>So, cars are the most convenient means of transportation for the majority of people.<n>The correct answer would be C: cars.<n>```<n><n>#### Hint 1<n>Cars<n><n>#### Hint2<n>Cars are used by most people, not helicopters, not own cars <n><n>#### Hint3<n>Speak words can not transport<n><n>#### Hint4<n>Car is the only one which transport people<n><n>### Instructions: A man got a promotion and wants to buy a bigger house, which will require more furniture. The number of people with whom he might share a bed, the various types of furniture that might be in a bedroom, and the advantages and drawbacks of renting items instead of purchasing them were among the topics discussed<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Rationael:<n>In the first paragraph of the question, we were given some examples of different types of furniture. Then, the second paragraph tells us that<n>- there are different kinds of beds<n>- a man would need more furnishings<n>- the man wants to buy a new house.<n>These facts enable us to make a conclusion:<n><n>### The correct answer, then, is E: rent items rather than purchasing them unless absolutely necessary, as only this answer choice would be logical given the given information.

Choices:  A: bite B: lie down C: keep alive D: need to eat E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: bite<n><n>The word tired has the connotation of exhaustion and the need to rest. It is quite likely that the animal in this scenario is exhausted and therefore needs to rest. Biting is a common behavior among certain animals, such as dogs and snakes, that exhibits physical exhaustion and the need for rest. Hence, A is the correct answer.<n><n>Answer: <n>### TASK: A book that is well written, informative, and interesting can be what? Choices: A: well-thinned B: well-printed C: well-read D: well-formed E: well-bound<n>Answer: <n>A: well-written<n>While a book may be well-formed, well-printed, well-bound, and so on, the phrase "well-written" provides the most specific information about the quality of this book. The phrase clearly implies that this book is well-written in terms of language and content. By carefully reading the context of the sentence, we can conclude that the book is informative, interesting, and engaging.<n><n>Answer: Answers: <n>### Input:The city made what up of the land after the war. Choices: A: a mess B: a jungle C: a junk place D: a jungle E: a forest<n>Answer: B: a junglesome<n><n>The question states that the city made something out of the land after the "war." Since the context is vague and does not provide any other relevant information, we can assume that the city is recovering from some kind of devastating event.<n><n>When the question gives specific clues that point in one direction, it is important to carefully read the information provided. In this case, the mention of a "war" gives us a strong indication that the city is recoverinig from a war. Additionally, the question states that the city has "made something out of the land," suggesting that the city has taken the opportunity to rebuild or redevelop the area.<n><n>The description given in the question is vague enough that "a mess" could be a plausible answer, but the context gives us more specific information. In conclusion, "a junglesome" is the correct answer because it is the only one that accurately describes the situation being described by the question.<n><n>##<n>### Explanation:<n><n>

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Output:<n>Answer: D: composted  <n><n>Burned - this is not reflected and would not be visible in the piece of wood due to the absence of water. <n><n>Polished - polishing or shining a piece of wood is not relevant in the context of the question, and hence is not the correct answer.<n><n>Carved - the question mentions the "piece of wood" not a piece of wood with carving, so this answer is incorrect.<n><n>Naked - having a wood carving with no paint or polish would be unrelated to this question, so this answer is not correct. <n><n>Composted - this is correct.

This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Bob thought that his Pokemon cards were common and worthless, but he was wrong about them. They were really what? Choices:  A: personal B: special C: shiny D: rare E: irregular<n><n>### Response:		C: shiny<n><n>### Demerits:This answer has a small amount of spelling, punctuation, and grammar errors.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Simon bought a cow because he wanted to put it to work.   He didn't want any meat for it.  Where might Simon be taking the cow? Choices:  A: countryside B: city C: dairy farm D: butcher shop E: canada<n><n>### Response:		<n>In this case, I do not believe there is sufficient proof to exclude the answer choices 'countryside' and 'dairy farm'. They are both options that are plausible given what there is in the question.<n><n>Answer A: countrysiiide<n>Answer B: dairy farm<n><n>### Input : Simon bought a cow because he really want to put it to work what he didn't want any meats for it where might Simon be taking the co? Choices:  a: country side b: dairy farm c: butcher shop d: canada E : none of them<n><n>### Response :<n>In this, there are a lot of different answer choices which are all plausible and are all somewhat logical options, given what is stated in the question. It might be useful to see the question as two separate parts: the first part (where Simon bought a cow because...) is a very general sentence that offers contextual clues for the second part (but doesn't actually specify what the context is).<n><n>First, we have the question of what, exactly, the cow is being put to work with. It was bought to work, so it shouldn't just be grazing or being a pet or having its life as an end in itself. Rather, it is "put to work" for something.<n><n>In the second part of the question, we have the clue of Simon not wanting any meat from the cow, but there is no real information as to what this is in relation to. If the question had been phrased 'Simon bought a cow to put to work and didn't want it for meat. Where is Simon going to keep the cow?', we have clarification about what the meat might be going for (butcher shop) and we also have an added incentive and additional motivation for Simon to keep the cow in the dairy farm.<n><n>Finally, we could see this question as stating what Simon didn't want, but not what he did want. This would indicate that his motive for acquiring the cow may lie in some kind of non-meat use. However, this is assuming the question does not contain important information that we do not know is present in the question.

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What building has a ot of glue bottles? Choices:  A: art room B: police station C: classroom D: desk drawer E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>As a student, I spend my days in a classroom, but it has never been covered or decorated with lots of glue bottles. Rather, it’s full of bubbling pondering, erasers and pencil shavings, homework problems for the teacher to correct, and occasional glue stains from art projects.<n><n>### Input<n>Having lots of glue bottle in a building means the building is art room<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>There are a few common ways that the term “bottles” might be used related to a building or property, and none of them apply here:<n><n>- When we say a person has a “bottle” of a certain substance, we’re referring to bottles of an alcoholic beverage, like whiskey. Unless this building contains a bar, this isn’t what is meant in the question.<n>- If we are referring to bottles of medication the first thing to note is that there is no medication involved in the example in the question and that the building’s contents would be incompatible with most medications; therefore, it makes no sense to refer to a building as a “bottle of medicine,” regardless of what kind.<n>- The phrase “bottles of water” is commonly used to describe the drink bottles a person is carrying. The building is neither a student taking water bottles to school nor a worker who brings bottles of water back from a job site. The context of the question clearly indicates that we are not dealing with bottles of water.<n>- Like “medicine bottles” and “bottles of drinks, “bottles of perfume” is also not relevant, as we are clearly not dealing with perfume, only glue bottles.<n>- Similarly, “bottles used to sell or store foods,” or “bottles used in cooking” are not at all related to the question. The concept of cooking can be narrowed down to “in a kitchen or kitchen area” and is irrelevant to the context of the question.<n>- Likewise, we could be talking about bottles for fire in a firehouse; however,the context suggests a school or college, and there is no indication here that the building is used for fire protection or as a residence.<n>- The phrase "a bottle of something" is

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Jimmy didn't like going to the party.  It seemed like the guys there did nothing but what? Choices:  A: dance B: getting drunk C: meet new people D: having fun E: have fun<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n><n>### Input 2: I didn't want to do any more homework today and just did everything it really what to do? Choices:  B: what is it A: what am I doing C: what I was doing E: going to do<n>---<n>```<n>The question could be something like :I didn't want to finish my homework and just did everything it REALLY what to do or I didn't want finish my homework today and just do everything what I REALLY what to? <n>```<n>1. The key to the answer is "did everything", so the action in this statement must have been one that could be done in every sense (without an option to "do", which limits the choice).<n>2. The context of the question then is that of studying and homework, so any action or statement in this regard would fit.<n>3. The second part of the question mentions that the speaker wanted to do something else, this suggests that whatever they did was not what they wished to do but what they ended up doing despite their intention to do something else instead.<n>4. We can therefore logically eliminate choices A and C as there are "I" and "wash" in these choices, which seem too specific for general use as opposed to what could be done in every case (without the "what"). <n>5. Choices B and E are also too specific in their phrasing; they can be considered as eliminations, although they may not fit in the context exactly they could also be potential choices.<n>6. The context also indicates that the act involved in the question is going to involve some type of work, so something that requires less effort is likely, and so choice D is eliminated.<n>7. Finally, based on our analysis, the most logical choice would be B: what am I doing, which fits the context and provides a grammatically correct option to fill the gap. <n>Answer: B: what am I doigng<n><n>### Input : The question to what you do that always makes you cry? Choices:  D: nothing in the world but what A: no but the fact that my parents don't understand what is happening to me. E: no except for what <n>---<n>```<n>What could you do that always makes cry or make me cry.  To do what and me<n>```<n>1. "what" seems like a bit odd

Choices: 1) The environment will be more supportive now 2) They will be better at managing their time 3) They will feel more comfortable with the change 4) It will be less demanding 5) They will be in control Question 2<n><n>### Rationales: 1) The first sentence gives us an idea of the type of change involved. A person is being "promoted" to a higher level, suggesting a "new" or "different" job.<n>2) "Stress management" is a phrase or keyword we often hear in job-related situations. This indicates that the subject is most likely to have experienced stress or uneasiness in their previous work position.<n>3) The sentence in which the job change is mentioned, "reducing stress associated with the new job" provides more clues about the context. These two sentences tell us that (a) the change was stressful enough for the subject to consider changing the job, (b) the subject experienced stress or uneasyness related to work.<n>4) In the given sentence, we can see that the main character is contemplating the pros and cons of a new job, thus we can assume that they have made it to the higher level, so stress management probably becomes important for them. Also, we see that they are looking for the "less demanding" part of the change, supporting the answer C, relaxation.<n><n><n>### Input:-Why is the subject looking for the less demanding part of the change to the new job?-Can you think of any reasons why stress management might be challenging?<n><n>### Rationale:  -In the sentence "The subject is looking for the less demand stress", we can easily see that it is the new change or position that becomes less demanding for the subject due to new experiences, skills and knowledge.<n>-It probably becomes hard to relax or manage the stress, as the person is overwhelmed by all the new and probably, unknown responsibilities and expectations that the change brings.<n>### Instructions:Choose the best answer to this question.<n><n>## Input:-Why is the situation less stressful for the new executive?<n><n>### Options:-They are doing much the same work in their new job.<n>### Options

Choices:  A: battle field B: museum C: weapon D: canon E: tornado<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: The question gives us no indication where the ball will be found, so its location will not provide any clue to the answer, nor will one of the options, which are all irrelevant.<n>The question also does not say whether the war is past or present. The past tense would not make much sense if the war is ongoing, so the "war" question refers to past, most likely as opposed to present.<n><n>The question refers to bullet projectiles, which is highly specific. Bullets are small and usually fired quickly in huge amounts. Also, most bullets are metal, indicating the object referred to in the question is metal.<n><n>The "bullet" referred to in the question could have been fired by:<n>    - A machine gun, which, as a weapon, is most likely to fire bullets.<n>    - A canon, which, to our knowledge, does not shoot bullets but is generally made of metal.<n><n>Taking into account the context, "bullets" in the question indicate projectiles.<n>Thus, taking into account the fact that most war cannons were made of metal but not all bullets were, the most logical answer is: C: weapon.<n><n>Answer: C: weapon<n><n>

When a paper notice is delivered, the person will have a paper notice then place it on the front door. This will be the first reaction after picking up the notice.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>In other hand, the paper notice will not be found placed on front door. Angry person will feel irate after getting the bill. There will be no such reactions like confusion or indifference.<n><n>### Answer Explanation:<n>If Mr. Hume is surprised by the bill and he is not expecting the taxi driver to charge such extra amount of the bill, then Mr. Hume will be confused by this. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What is a place that could have hundreds of sporting goods store? Choices:  A: ocean B: desk C: universe D: attic E: chair<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is C, universe<n>### Explanation<n>"Where would you put a (something not something)" makes you think of the opposite in terms of where you may not put someting else. For example, if the question said "Where would you put a chair?" you may think of removing a chair from your house, you may not imagine putting a chair in the ocean. So you would be very unlikely to put a chair in the ocean because that makes the sentence false.<n><n>### To clarify further, I will give you another example:<n>"Where would you store coffee beans?" What would you answer? You couldn't put your coffee beans in the ocean and you probably wouldn't put them in the chair! You could put them in a big box. And that is correct for this question because if you put your answer as anything else besides universe then in that case, the question becomes false.<n><n>## Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question, while demonstrating each of the required criteria.<n><n>### Input:"A" has the largest base of all prime numbers, and thus, contains the most digits. Because of that, it has fewest digits.<n><n>### Rationales:<n> - Question 1:<n>     - Question makes you understand the question.<n>	 <n> - Question 2<n>     - A question that makes you wonder about the answer and whether or not it is correct.<n>	 <n>  - Question 3<n>      - A question that makes the answer obvious.<n><n>### A<n>    - "A" contains the most digits.<n>

Choices:  A: asia B: southern hemisphere C: planet D: east E: earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the subject of the question were a Martian, they would not know anything about Earth. Given that they are driving, the question must be asking a question that a pilot would ask to figure out the meaning of a point on the map. The choice "Asia" is not a good answer because it does not look like a sea that was named after a location on the map in the original question. However, the other answers are all countries, which means that the planet of Earth or a group of people called the "Indians" might have found the Indian Ocean. The next best answer is then "Southern Hemisphere," because this is the only name of a planet that is not human in origin. The other answers make sense but are not answers to the question: "Where would a Martian need to go to find the Indian Ocean?". The correct answer to the question is then "Southen Hemisphere."<n><n>### Input : If the sun rose in the afternoon, how would this result in? Choices:  I: people driving to work and other activities would increase, as everyone would want to be up and active during the day. K: fewer people would be traveling during the day, as everyone would have to stay inside and staying inside during the day. H: everyone would be at work during the day and at the same office during the day, as the sun would be up anyway.<n><n>### Response :<n>During the time that there is a lot of light, people tend to be more awake. If the sun rises during the day, there would be a sunrise. If there was a sunrise, every one would be awake during the day. This is why K is a possible answer. However, the question does not ask what will happen when the sun rises during a day. It is asking about what will happen if there was a sunset during the day. There would be very little light in the evening because of the sunset. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:If you are fiddling through a music book when you should be playing, you probably dont have? Choices:  A: practice B: dexterity C: idle time D: knowledge of music E: conductor<n><n>### Response:		A: idle time<n>### Justification:<n>This question has some elements in common with the previous question that dealt with what you would be fantasizing about. It also, like the previous question, starts with a phrase stating that whatever the answer is, it probably doesnt involve or entail. <n><n>In this case, the phrase is "If you are fidding through a music book when [...] you probably don't have?" which could be interpreted a couple of different ways. <n><n>First, without context, this suggests the subject in question has probably never played through a music book, implying lack of practice. <n><n>A different way to interpret it is by removing "fidding" and examining whether there are consequences or possible causes of "fidding through a music that you probably don't know". <n><n>If the subject were fiddling through the book, it would suggest they were lacking the dexterity, or the skill to play and be able to flawlessly handle a music book. <n><n>However, neither one of the answers provided satisfy the second requirement as both, A and B, can be true and false regarding idle time, dexterity, music knowledge etc. The question is not satisfied as none of them are able to provide us with a reasonable response.<n><n>The phrase "you probably don't have", however, is something that needs to be kept in mind. Idleness will cause idle time, which is the answer we want. <n><n>So, if you start playing, you will probably lose your idle time, and your dexterity with the book as well. Thus, we can answer to the question that the most reasonable alternative is idle time. Answer: A: idle time.<n><n>### Input : How did you know the difference between your friend's boss and a grizzly bear? Choices:  A: jigsaw puzzle B: chess game C: puzzle box D: jigsaw puzzel puxxle E: puxxle<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A: chess game B: jigsaw puzzler C: puzzle box E: puxxal D: puzzle puzzler F: jig saw puzzler<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:The word PUZZLES has an O in the middle making it SOL as seen in the image below.<n><center><n><img src="https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/figma-alpha-api/files/3549281038412287557/df24262b-a93c-4dff-9a9d-09a6dd51008c/image.png" width = "250px" height = "250"><n></img><n></center><n><n>### Process:<n>1. Split the word with a vertical line.<n>2. Use an H letter as a mirror to the original L so it's like you're making an H on the other side.<n>3. Place a circle in that space.<n>4. Create an upside down U above the H and add an E at the end.<n>5. Place a space between the two words so that it is pronounced as one whole word.<n>Process ends here.<n><n>### Example:<n>### Instruction (1):The word "PUZZLES" has an O in the center.<n>### Instruction 2:Split the word with a vertical division.<n>### Instruxction 3:Write the word from left to right in alphabetical order.<n>### Demonstruction:<n><center><n>    <img src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Puzzles.svg/320px-Puzzles.svg.png" width = 250px height = 250><n></img><n><n>### Demosrtration:<n>1. Split puzzles with a vertical line. 2. Write the original P from left to right. 3. Write "S" from right to left. 3. Write"UL" from left to right.  4. Write "Z" from right to left .

Hence, B can be disregarded.<n><n>- If we decided to look at C, it would be more logical to look in the table area. A table would not be an efficient place for a dictionary, as it is portable, so we will need to take the dictionary with us to a table. Hence, C can be disregarded as well.<n><n>- If the student is really using an online dictionary, or is taking an exam, he or she would not have to bring a dictionary with them. When a student is trying to concentrate, there are almost no other thoughts that would be possible, so whatever would pop into their mind would be about the task at hand, most likely one related to school or classes. The student might think about the subject they are supposed to write down or draw a picture of, or about the teacher or classmates, or about school itself, its rules, and so on. Therefore, there would be a mixture of thoughts, but most likely some school-related ones would pop into a student's mind when they can't concentrate. The correct answer would be School-related.

Choices:  A: sitting down B: excitement C: tiredness D: progress E: procrastination<n><n>### Response:		<n>1.The key to this question is using an inference technique, which means to understand the context of the situation and the motivations for why it would be happening. In this case, the sentence is telling us that the reader is finding it hard to start work, so the subject might not be motivated to do the job.<n>2.If the subject was excited then they should already be in a state of high energy. This makes A and D as incorrect answers.<n>3.The question refers to the act of sitting down:  "if you have trouble beginning work". Using a keyword spotting technique, we can eliminate sitting because it doesn’t relate to the motivations. Therefore, we can assume that the problem isn’t one of motivation but rather an act of sitting down.<n>4.If the subject is tired, then why would they be sitting down? Therefore, we can eliminate C and B.<n>5.If the subject begins work with no problems then why does he/she find it hard to begin work? In this situation you would eliminate E and D.<n>6.This leaves us with B, E, and F.<n>7.To decide which answer would be the most correct it is important to pay attention to the question. The question is asking "if you have trouble with beginning work, you are suffering from what? "  The reader is suffering from beginning work so there must be something holding them back.<n>8.To decide which answer was the correct answer we can look at the question "if you have trouble begin work you are suffering from what?" We can ask ourselves "Which situation would most likely keep a person from beginning work?" B sounds the most logical and thus the answer is B: 'sitting down'.<n><n>Answer: B:Sitting Down<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What is a lover likely to want to do with their partner? Choices:  A: become depressed B: welcome change C: thank god D: experiences E: pay bills<n><n>### Response:		<n>The clue "welcome change" suggests that we are looking for things that involve significant change. As a result, we would not expect to find someone "welcome" changes like paying bills or thanking God for their blessings. Instead, a person looking for new, interesting things in life might seek them out, which supports option C.<n><n>### Input :The thing he did as he was walking home that surprised many people that night? Choices:  I) he was angry about his job  II) he was happy  III) did it anyways  IV) left early<n><n>### Answer:<n>We learn in the text (line 3) that the subject was walking towards home. This suggests that he lived somewhere, which suggests he was away from home when the incident occurred. As a result, this is most likely occurring during nighttime. The first possibility, (I) he was angry about is his job, is easily ruled out as the subject was on the way home. He would not have been angry about his job if he was already at home. If the subject was angry at work, he would likely not be heading towards home, which is the logical conclusion. As a result, he was happy (II) was a logical solution because this would explain why he was smiling.<n>

Choices:  A: hurry along B: direct traffic C: help D: force open door E: corner thief<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The policemen wanted to [clear the scene of the accident](https://www.thefreedictionary.com/clearing+scene+of). So, what did they do to [traffic?](https://www.theguardian.com/wordoftheday/2012/dec/06/clear-traffic-danger) They [hurried along](https://dictionary.cambridge.org/us/dictionary/english/hurry-along). They [directed](https://dictionary.famiglenews.net/definition/1738) traffic. They helped drivers. They [cornered](https://www.lexic.us/definition/corner) and [took a thief](https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.grammarly.com/blog/past-tense-use/amp/) to the station house. All these are the ways in which the police officers cleared the scene of the accident. So, the correct answer is \#4. They [corner](https://www.macmillandictionary.com/dictionary/american/corner) and took a thief to the station house.<n>

Therefore, the most accurate answer would be "A: birthday party."<n><n>### Input:#Both the what and the how refer to something's use so they can be understood to be either a product or a process. Both things in the sentence can be referred to as "tools." #The "what" and "how" in the sentence could refer to either the product (a tool) or the process (how to use a tool). #The fact that they both start with the same letter (tool) should be considered a hint as to the possibility of a double meaning. #Another possible, logical answer would be "the how," referring to how a tool is used. This answer should be eliminated based on the ambiguity of the sentences grammatical structure—if the statement referred to how something is use, it would be "how do you use a tool?" #The statement "the answer is what" would not make any sense if this sentence is meant to refer to the act of using, as the sentence is supposed to refer to the act rather than the product. #Finally, since both tools and tools are both written as plural words, the sentence should be understood to be referring to the product in question.#<n><n>### Instructions:Find the word/group of words in italics that creates a misleading ambiguity in the sentence in #. <n><n>### Demesnation:#In the sentence (c), the word "the" does not refer to anything. "The" is supposed to refer to "what." Consequently, the structure of this sentence is misleading.<n><n>### Input, Response:You should give yourself a boost mentally by doing what?  A: exercising B: learning C: singing D: getting more sleep <n><n>An answer, B: learning, C: singing, is a combination that creates a misleading grammatical structure.<n><n>### Answers, Response:One way to avoid this type of error is to reword the sentence so that what and how are placed in context of their parts of speech by omitting "how do you do it?" in the original response. Answer A: exercise and answer C: sing.<n><n>### In the last sentence the word:<n><n>### Input Answer: I saw something. My father had the n

Carolina or Georgia.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>    - The question mentions cotton balls, and cotton comes originally from South America and South Africa, hence, B is correct.<n>        <n>### Question:<n>An 1860 essay written by Robert Penn Warren.<n><n>### Answer:<n>I'm not sure if the question should be, what did Robert Penn Warren write in 1860? Or, what was Robert Penn Warren writing in 1862? It continues to say that "he had in mind a larger work"; however, there was an 18th century essay published by Warren named "Confederate in Europe" which was published in a magazine. So, which is it? Did he write the book, or did he write the essay?<n><n>### 2.<n>It mentions that it is an 1860's essay written by Robert Warren. So, to me, that means it is dated 1860 or possibly 1862 depending on the answer to the first point I made.<n><n>### Now, the only questions I'm left with are, did Robert Penn Warren make a 1860 book about his experience in the Civil War, or wrote the Confederate essay, did they publish in the 1800's or the 1860s.<n><n>After searching, it seems it was written either 1860-1862.<n><n>### Question: What happened to the young actor and young boy from the play "Into The Woods" when Stephen Sondheim saw them both?<n><n>### Answer<n>The young actor was 19 and was called "an unbelievable talent" by Stephen Sondheim. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What is important in a car when you are driving fast and come to a light? Choices:  A: stripes B: seat belts C: breaks to help stop D: tires E: radios<n><n>### Response:		<n>Driving fast is not good because it will cause accidents which could cause death. This was in the video and the lesson. Choices: A: stripes C: breaks to help slow down a speeding vehicle D: tires<n><n>### Explain:A person does not notice something very important until after the fact.<n><n>### Input 1: What would you do for the best way to fix a flat tire? Choices:  Xing: turn around and use another tire A: use a different part of the vehicle B: call police C: change the tire D: stop car E: call a mechanic<n><n>### Input2: Use the words on the list to help answer questions.<n><n>- break - something you use to control your car<n>- car - vehicle<n>- fix - repair<n>- light - signal<n>- car - drive<n>- flat - level<n>- tire - vehicle<n>- repair - fix<n>- control - prevent harm<n><n>Explain:A person does fix until a tire is flat. They notice it after the problem occurs.<n><n>### Answer:<n>Answer 1: The word "fix" means repair, and the subject of the sentence (the person driving) notices a problem only after it was caused. Hence, the person does not notice the problem until after they tried to fix it, concluding that the correct answer must be C, change a flat tire.<n><n>Answer 2: The first question indicates that the subject will use the words given in the list to complete the sentences. In the second question, this is phrased as "Use the words on the list... answer questions," conveying it as the subject of the sentence will, indeed, use the words on the list as answers to questions.<n><n>### Response 3:<n><n>Answer 3: The question implies the usage of the words 'break' and vehicle while driving. The subject in the first question mentioned in this answer is a person driving a car. Hence, the correct combination of words is a person using their car to respond to a flat tire, in which the word "car" needs to replace "vehicle" to maintain the logical structure described. Therefore, the correct answer is A, use a car as a replacement.<n>

Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:David hurt all over. He was tired, he was shaking, and he was in pain.  He hadn't gotten what he needed in a long time.  He was suffering from what? Choices:  A: addiction B: fatigue C: relaxation D: headaches E: over eating<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D: headaches<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. This question states that the subject "hurt all over," which implies both physical and emotional pain. While addiction can also have a physical component, the statement that "he hadn't gotten [what he needed] in a long time" does not imply a long term, continuous situation. This suggests a more recent event, and a more recent event suggests something that happened recently over a long period of time. Addiction is a chronic disease and so is unlikely to develop over so few hours.<n>2. The next sentence, "He was tired, he was [shaking,] and he was in pain" clearly refers to the state he was in before he got what he needed. "Was" suggests the actions happened in the past, while "tired" clearly refers to fatigue.<n>3. "He hadn't gotten..." and "he was in pain" could also refer to an injury, like a headache. While this is possible, the final sentence states that David had not gotten what he needed "in a long time." This would imply that he had gotten some help before. "Over eating" is therefore also excluded.<n>4. In summary, the most likely possibility here is the "over eating" David was likely to have gained from a meal, rather than an eating disorder, leading to headaches. Therefore, the correct answer is D: headaches, which can be obtained from the question stem and subsequent context of information.<n><n><n>### Input:"She is being treated poorly at work because she is getting older," answered a colleague. Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>The correct answer is: C - A movie had many a song & dance it was a musical.<n>```<n>Explain:<n>The word 'a' means 'one':<n><n>The word'many' means'many':<n><n>Movie means: Moving picture shown as entertainment<n><n>Singing and acting: Music and dance<n><n>A movie has many a song and dance. Hence, that sentence is, - The problem at the back of the novel is the mystery's.<n><n>Answer: The problem at the back the mystery's is the novel<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>The mystery's problem at the back of its jacket is what's?<n>```<n>##### Response<n>```<n>In the above sentence, the first word 'the' means 'that's':<n><n>Mystery -> A puzzling and mysterious problem<n><n>The  mystery's problem at its back is'what's'<n>```<n>##### Correct Answer<n>```<n>The mystery- puzzling; a mystery novel<n><n>The mystery's -> That's the mystery<n><n>The mystery -> That is a mystery<n><n>Mystery's problem at its -> Back at the back -> The mystery's problem back at the back <n><n>Mystery`s problem back at its back<n><n>Mystery- Back at the back 'the' mystery's' problem<n><n>The mystery `s` problem back at its back is'that's what'<n><n>The mystery ` s`  problem at the back of is 'that is what's <n><n>Answer: The mystery back at the jacket is its problem.<n>The mystery` s`

This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:After the guilty verdict in the killing the judge gave a speech, he told the murderer he was pure what? Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n><n>### Response:		A: wrong. The sentence suggests that the accused was found guilty, and thus is not guilty even if he in fact is, which contradicts the judge's characterization. A death verdict would be "death of" the accused, and this is not what the judge said. "Bad" and "evil" also do not make sense. As for "negative," this is a valid answer, but is perhaps too general to be as strongly implied as the other ones in the question.<n><n>Answer: A: wrong<n><n>### Input:"You are what you do" the man said, to the man. And they both went home together, both angry and annoyed. A: man B: men C: both D: the men E: none of the above<n><n>### Response:"You are what you did" has two words in it, which is a strong indication that the answer contains two words, too. The sentence is unclear, and therefore we can neither answer B: men, since it is unclear what "two went home together" refers to, nor E: none of the answers, since it is unclear if the words are referring to one or both of the men. The question is grammatically correct, so "you are what you did" would be the correct answer had something been omitted from the sentence. As indicated by the "and" in the sentence, there is indeed something more to the sentence, so the question should read "You are what you did. And?" <n>"A: man" is the only answer that fits, since it is the only correct answer that makes sense in the sentence. "B: both" would contradict the original sentence, as would "C: both angry and annoyed."<n><n>Answer: A : man<n><n>### Input"Do you know what I did last night?" A: Yes B: No C: I don't know D: I know E: I'm not sure<n><n>### ResponseI'm not sure:  The sentence is ambiguous, suggesting the asker did several different things at the night he is asking about. This would be a more accurate response.<n><n>Answer: E: I'm sure<n><a href="https://www.instructables.com/id/What-I-did-during-my-vacation-at-school-I-enjo/"><n>  https://www.instructable.com
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:The billionaire donated a large sum to his former college, this allowed them to construct a new science what? Choices:  A: fraternity house B: bank C: big town D: big city E: building<n><n>### Response:		(answers in same order)<n><n>I)<n><n>The first hint given in the problem is that the billionaire donated a sum to his former college. Because we do not know what he donated it to, our analysis should remain broad and non-specific. The answer to this question is likely to be something uncommon at a business school, but not specific to only one industry, like finance or technology. Thus, we can discount choices "B" (bank), "C" (big town), "D" (big city), and "E" (building).<n><n>II)<n><n>A second hint is given in the problem in the sentence, "this allowed them to construct a... building," suggesting that whatever is being constructed in the same sentence is what is being financed.<n><n>This allows us to eliminate choice "A" (fraternity house), which does not directly relate to the work or business world. Eliminating this gives us choices:<n>C: big town,<n>D: big city,<n>and E: building.<n><n>III)<n><n>Emerging from the context, we can then analyze each of the remaining choices more closely. Choice "D" seems to be the correct choice because (1) "big" usually refers to "broad" or "large" or "large amount," indicating that the science building in question is large, and (2) given that the building will be constructed with donations from the billionaire, "big" may be a euphemism for "large" or "donated." It makes sense that someone wealthy enough to donate a billion dollars can construct something large.<n><n>Answer: C: big town<n><n>### Input:[1] You can make it  back up before it finish this  you can make   this faster if this you  make this as a sub question you can  make this not so big if this you  make  some one can   make this   for me<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question by submitting the correct response.<n><n>### Input([2]): 1.  <n>### Instruction:[1] You can do this because a)this 2.  <n>### Input ([3][4]): you can do this because this? 3.  <n>### Demonstraition([1]): 1. The total of people who say they work part time is 10% less than 20%, thus the percentage of people who work full time is (5/796) + (10% * 796) = about 30%<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:If an actor is said to be on the “silver screen" where would you see them perform? Choices:  A: play B: movies C: theater D: screen E: television<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct option is B: movies. From the context, we can understand that "The silver screen" is a place where actors perform movies, usually on a big screen. Hence, the correct choice would be B: movies.<n><n>### Input<n>It will no longer be the role of the FDA to issue public health advisories about which drugs are safe, the agency’s commissioner said, but it will instead be the responsibility of ________________? Choices: 1. A: drug manufacturer B: drug distributors C: health care providers D: pharmacies E: federal government<n><n>### Rationales<n>From the context, we can infer that the FDA is trying to do something about the issue of drugs with harmful ingredients causing a health risk for the consumers. This is one of their core responsibilities, and the statement made indicates that it is no longer working well. The term "role" can signify the actor performing this task, thus implying that the person is an agency or institution. This points to the federal government, as one way the government ensures the safety of its people is by performing duties related to their health. Therefore, the correct answer is E: federal government.<n><n>### Other Options<n>A: drug manufacturer. Drug manufacturers are responsible for checking their products for safety, but not the general public. Even if the drugs are harmful and there is an advisory, it is not the responsibility of a drug manufacturer to distribute this information.<n><n>B: drug distributors. Drug distributors are responsible for making sure there are enough prescription drugs to go around, however, FDA advisories are about drugs that are unsafe for consumption by the general public and not about drugs that might lack sufficient stock.<n><n>C: health care providers. Even though health care providers, such as doctors and nurses may use drugs, these advisories are about ensuring the safety of the general public.<n><n>D: pharmacies. Pharmacies are not expected to issue advisories, but rather to check for the safety of drugs brought to them for purchase.

Each round, four players are picked to answer the quiz questions. 2. Two will always lose, one will always win. 3. Each round ends with the players moving seats. 4. Before the game ends, each player must complete three quiz rounds.  Which of the following rules requires you to remain in your current seat when the game ends? Choices: ☐ A: Pick one. ☐ B: Sit at the end of the table. ☐ C: Both of the above. ☐ D: Pick any. ☐ E: Neither<n><n>### Response"C" - Both require you to stay in your current seat.<n><n>### Rationale for answer:<n>Quiz rounds require you to stay in the same seat. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:What is someone unintentionally hurting someone else but unable to stop likely to feel? Choices:  A: empowering B: regret C: despair D: glee E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		<n>The above question is describing a situation like what someone is trying to stop someone from hurting themselves and isn't allowed to do anything about it. They continue to see this happening and have to suffer themselves. Thus, they must feel unstoppable.<n>In this situation, they're trying to stop themselves from hurting someone. They keep feeling sad for it and they feel sadness that keeps on going. But they can't hurt themselves because they're stopping themself. Thus, the correct answer is E: Sadness.<n><n>### Input The boy who cried wolf was a young shepherd that repeatedly lied about a wolf's presence in order to escape work. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to sore a wind instrument in you home? Choices:  A: sleep B: feel more comfortable C: sweating D: blush E: cuddle<n><n>### Response:		<n>Your task is to decide on the best answer for the question. <n><n>### Your submission in the solution below will not include any of the contextual information present in the question and will consist of either Choices A or B, (or both), which are listed below:<n><n>### Answer:<n>     * Choices E<n><n><n>### Rationale:<n>    * A: sleep is something that's usually done as a way to calm oneself, or to relax, which would suggest that the person in the blanket is feeling a little on edge or uncomfortable. That's not consistent with the rest of the context, and so it's not the correct answer.<n>    * Choice B: this makes no literal sense. The couch is the only object in the situation that's giving off heat, so it's not something that can make a person feel warmer.<n>    * Choices D and E make sense in this situation. The person is wrapped up in a blanket, so they may feel a bit blushy from all of the heat, and perhaps even feel the need to cuddle with a person or other object in their vicinity. Since there is only one blanket, and the couch is the only other object in the vicinity, it's the most logical answer.<n>

Choices:  A: ignore B: write C: learn new things D: illiterate E: having fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are a few reasons why this question could be confusing, the first is ambiguousness of the word "he wanted," while it is probably referring to the child, it does not offer any context, there is no gender hint, it could mean:<n>1. the child really wanted to do something, what was that? <n>2. the child really wanted the child to do something with his grandpa.<n>3. the child really wanted someone to teach the child something.<n>4. the child really wanted his grandpa to behave differently.<n><n>Another source of confusion would be the phrase "he ___ ____ his whole life." Here we can eliminate possibilities because some, like "learning new things" and "illiterate" would not apply to a person who had spent their entire life not doing them. "Having fun" or "ignoring" would also not apply to all of the time. The correct answer is A: "he learned something new," as the grammatical form of the last phrase, using past participles, states unequivocally.

Choices:  A: compliments B: passing grade C: intellectual challenge D: sticker E: avoid pain<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Analysis:<n>We want to narrow down our possibilities by using a process of elimination.<n>1. An answer choice that would receive compliments would be something that is done well. This would not require any skill; if it were, it would be a learned skill. Therefore, we can eliminate A: compliments.<n>2. Stickers and avoidance of pain are both actions, neither of which requires any skill at all. If this were to be a skill, it would be a physical skill - i.e. if the assignment itself did not require any problem-solving or thoughtfulness but rather just an accurate execution of the task, one would not need to possess any specific skills and could just avoid pain altogether if they performed the assignment according to the teacher's requirements. If a student didn't understand or misread the instructions, they would not avoid pain and would end up with low marks as they completed the assignment. This doesn't seem like a useful skill so we can eliminate E: avoid pain.<n>3. This leaves B: passing grade, C: intellectual challenge, and D: sticker as realistic possibilities. We are looking for a skill, and "sticker" is just an object and not a skill, hence we can eliminate D: sticker. The question tells us we need to find a skill, and we can reasonably expect that a student competent in their schoolwork would not be able to get a passing grade without doing something. Given that they have intellect and that this is in the realm of mental work, they would need to be good at using information (intellectual challenge). Therefore, the relevant choice is C: intellectual challenge and B: passing grade.<n><n>#### Conclusion:<n>The correct answer is A: B: passing grade and C: intellectul challenge<n><n>### Input What is a thing that is most likely if we have lots of time? If we have lots of time, we can do B) do nothing. Therefore, we can easily eliminate A) sleep and C) eat as a choice.<n>2. "to socialize" is an action as well. However the word "if" connects with the words following the

Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Rationales: 1. The question tells us that the subject is fantasizing about something while driving to work. This suggests that whatever they are fantasizing about is future-oriented and probably related to their job or work life.<n>2. The phrase "pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits" also provides a substantial hint. We can analyze it piece by piece:<n>    - "extra responsibilities" suggests an increase in the level of accountability or tasks, what would not arise from getting a new car, experiencing boredom, impatience, or pressure.<n>    - "benefits" often refers to advantageous or positive results from something, and is commonly used in a work context to refer to employee benefits. This narrows our possible answers even more, leaning towards something related to career advancement.<n>3. Taking into account the context and the analysis of the clues given in the problem, the most logical answer would be "promotion," as this is something one would fantasize about during a commute and indeed has both extra responsibilities and potential benefits. Hence, the correct answer is B: promotion.<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>### Input:Where is a notebook often purchased? Choices:  A: bookstore B: backpack C: abraham lincoln's grave D: desktop E: classroom<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question asks us to identify where a notebook would be bought.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>There are two different locations for where people might purchase a notebook. The answer will be either a bookstore or a classroom, as these are the only two places that someone could possibly purchase a notebook, unless they made one themselves.<n><n>### Input:$50.00 is what percent of $80.00? Choices:  -19% A:  -19 B:  -18.5  C:  -17.5  D:  -18% E:  -18<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The text provides the amount of the amount the amount of $26 divided by the original amount. For example, $50 is 100 percent of $50, or $80 is 106.7 percent of $75, or $100 is 111.1 percent of $88.75.<n><n>### Response<n>The amount $50 is 20.0 percent of the amount $250.<n><n>### Output:The amount $50.00<n><n>### Instructor comments<n>The task uses an inbuilt function called $% to calculate the percentage of a number. See the [Performing arithmetic with percentages](https://cloud.google.com/training/functions/docs/samples/calculate-percentages) section of the documentation for more on this.<n><n>### Task description:<n>You have been hired to create a function that performs the following mathematical operation:<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A number as a string or float64 type.<n><n>### Return value:<br/>A string type, with the value formatted as a percentage. For example,<n>the result 0.5 is returned as the string "50.0%" and the result 2 is returned as the string<n>"200.0%"<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: city B: downtown C: own house D: bar E: shopping center<n><n>### Response:		<n>This question has seven answers, which means there are seven correct answers and no incorrect answers, as shown below.<n><n>Answers: A -> D -> C -> E -> B -> D -> A<n><n>### Reasoning:<n>1) If the input has no errors, only answer choices that match it are valid answers. These are choices A through E.<n>2) If the input has extra spaces, either before or after the choices, or a space in the middle that should be absent, or wrong characters, these are all invalid answers.<n>3) If the input has more choices than the number of choices of a place to eat and a space to buy items, then the input is invalid; there are only 7 choices in the question, so extra spaces will make all answers invalid. If the input does not have these two conditions, then there are only 1 (seven) valid answers.<n><n>### Input How do you think a computer can do this work? Choices:  C A B D E<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: A computer can do this work by analyzing data and identifying patterns. The question refers to this work as "doing the work." While it's possible for computers to do work, they would not be able to "do the work" as described. Choices A and B each provide clues that suggest this type of work would require some kind of human effort; "give you advice" and "interact with you" can't be done by a computer alone. Choices C and D describe the same work as "gathering data," but do not specify that the computer does it. Choice E suggests human input, but is ambiguous with respect to the question of whether it would be sufficient or not. Choice C is correct, because it specifically refers to the work of finding patterns, which is something that a computer can do.<n><n>### Validation<n><n>1) If the only choices that exist are E and D, the input is invalid. This is because there are no other valid choices than these and this is the only option to select it.<n>2) If any choices that are not E or D are added, they are all invalid. This is because they are all incorrect, which would invalidate the input. In addition, the only other valid choice that exists is E, which means that any other choice will be invalid as they cannot possibly be correct.<n>3

I dont understand, any clues for this one?<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Input: The question is what might you read it for.<n>Rationales: You might read it for one or more purposes:<n>- To learn about it.<n>- To get news.<n>- To keep in touch or maintain contact.<n>- To keep up with what they are doing.<n>The question then clarifies that you might be reading a letter from a friend abroad. This provides even stronger hints for two purposes: <n>- To learn about where they live.<n>- To keep contact or maintain your relationship.<n>This again narrows down the list of possible options to two:<n>- To learn how their life has been while overseas. In this case, to seek knowledge of the world around them, "though" as a pronoun also suggests an analytical perspective.<n>-  To keep in touch. The subject seems friendly enough to be curious about their overseas friend. "Though" here adds nuance to our answer by suggesting that our subject is slightly distant or less friendly than they used to be. Hence we can conclude that the correct answer is B.<n><n>Answer: B: <n>In conclusion the subject seeks to know things about their overseas friends, thus, to keep in touch.<n><n>### Input : To get a better grade in his class he worked on his essay when it was due, had he been graded on a curve<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: To get a better grade he worked on his essays when they were due, so to get a better grade he should  have worked on them before they were due according to the logic of the question. Choices:  A: cinema B: opera C: party D: stage E: dance<n><n>### Response:		<n>This is a question that can be answered by process of elimination.<n><n>1. We know that a performer is at work, so Cinema would not be appropriate.<n>2. A performer is a performer is work, but not always. So, stage is invalid.<n>3. A stage is for a performer during a performance. Party is also invalid since this implies a party that this performer is invited to without being a performer.  <n>4. A gathering of friends is not always one that the friends are performing for. Dance is an invalid answer for this reason.<n>5. A performer has a performance. Therefore, party cannot be the answer either.<n><n>Hence, E: Opera is the correct choice for answer 5 since it is at an Opera where a performer performs and a party is a gathering of friends.<n><n>### Input : Choose the best matching answer for the idiom<n>1. In this scenario, there are several indicators that suggest that our subjects are thinking about something related to their job/work life, because they are driving. Additionally, we are told that the subject is fantasy about getting a something ("While driving to work the subject fantasies about getting something...") and that they are analyzing the pros and cons of whatever it is they are fantasizing (The pros and cons of....). Given the subject's apparent fascination with this new thing, we can analyze the situation and come up with plausible solutions (pros and cons of...).<n><n>One issue with the previous exercise is that no matter what the clues provided, no matter how well explained, I still couldn't tell what the "something" could be. There were too many possible things to look at (car, promotion, applesauce) and the text was very general about each of them. This is definitely a difficulty in understanding the clues.<n><n>## Instructions:  For both of the tasks above, did this exercise help you form a better understanding of what cognitive strategies you can best apply to a scenario when reading the task prompt, and applying information from the scenario text in a manner that will help you answer the problem as efficiently as possible?<n><n>## Demontration:  Yes, I think it would have been very challenging for me to successfully answer the question if my instructor had not already explained what strategy I should be looking for (the strategy being that I should take into account the clues provided in the text). To me, an exercise like this is meant to train us to identify, understand, and apply the appropriate strategies ourselves. I also found the use of these clues much more helpful than the direct instruction provided in the original question. Both strategies are useful and the most beneficial aspect would be to be able to identify the useful strategy and apply it intuitively in other situations.
